title: Setup CI build for Windows app
body: A Jenkins task should be created for Windows, [as we have](https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/tree/master/ci) for Linux and macOS. Currently waiting on the last step of #288 to be completed.

Some things need to be installed on the Windows machine used for the build, `PATH` needs to be setup correctly, etc. Please refer to the details in #620, #589, and #521.

Also, though I could be wrong, I think it's pretty important to run the make targets in *Git Bash directly on Windows*, as opposed to running in some other context like a Bash shell in Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).

Git Bash is included in installs of [Git for Windows](https://gitforwindows.org/).

As mentioned in #620:
> For CI builds Status will need to acquire a signing certificate from e.g. DigiCert. There will be a yearly renewal cost.
I've deployed a `windows-01` host and will now work here on getting the CI build to work.

Currently the build is failing with:
```
18:37:52  + make vendor/DOtherSide/build/lib/Release/DOtherSide.dll V=4
18:37:52  which gcc &>/dev/null || { echo "C compiler (gcc) not installed. Aborting."; exit 1; }
18:37:52  echo -e "\\e[92mBuilding:\\e[39m" "DOtherSide"
18:37:52  Building: DOtherSide
18:37:52  cd vendor/DOtherSide && \
18:37:52  	mkdir -p build && \
18:37:52  	cd build && \
18:37:52  	rm -f CMakeCache.txt && \
18:37:52  	cmake -T"v141" -A x64 -DENABLE_DYNAMIC_LIBS=ON -DENABLE_STATIC_LIBS=OFF\
18:37:52  		-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
18:37:52  		-DENABLE_DOCS=OFF \
18:37:52  		-DENABLE_TESTS=OFF \
18:37:52  		..  && \
18:37:52  	cmake --build . --config Release 
18:37:52  -- Building for: NMake Makefiles
18:37:52  CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:3 (project):
18:37:52    Generator
18:37:52  
18:37:52      NMake Makefiles
18:37:52  
18:37:52    does not support platform specification, but platform
18:37:52  
18:37:52      x64
18:37:52  
18:37:52    was specified.
18:37:52  
18:37:52  
18:37:52  CMake Error: CMAKE_C_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage
18:37:52  CMake Error: CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage
18:37:52  -- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
18:37:52  See also "C:/Users/jenkins/workspace/client_windows_ci-windows-builds/vendor/DOtherSide/build/CMakeFiles/CMakeOutput.log".
18:37:52  mingw32-make: *** [Makefile:183: vendor/DOtherSide/build/lib/Release/DOtherSide.dll] Error 1
```
https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/windows/job/ci-windows-builds/11/console

Which indicates that I probably need to either adjust `PATH` or set `CMAKE_C_COMPILER` and `CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER`.
cmake is supposed to build `DOtherSide.dll` with msvc instead of mingw's gcc. Is msvc available on the Windows host?

I'm not sure what's the best way in CI to install the build tools (if they're not installed) but here's a link:

https://aka.ms/buildtools

(found in a Microsoft [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/cppblog/announcing-visual-c-build-tools-2015-standalone-c-tools-for-build-environments/) though the link has been updated to point to the latest version of the tools)

If you're talking about Visual C++ Redistributable then I install it via `scoop` as [`vcredist2017`](https://github.com/lukesampson/scoop-extras/blob/master/bucket/vcredist2017.json):
https://github.com/status-im/infra-ci/blob/788658acca0dfe509ddcea8cf9ace0719ab399e8/files/windows_startup_script.ps1#L49-L50

There are issues in Scoop to add Visual Studio build tools:

* https://github.com/lukesampson/scoop-extras/issues/1861
* https://github.com/lukesampson/scoop-extras/issues/3159

Which suggest using this might work:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/use-command-line-parameters-to-install-visual-studio?view=vs-2019
@michaelsbradleyjr could you show what are your settings for `CMAKE_C_COMPILER` and `CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER` when you compile this on your system? What specific binary is used in your builds?

Sorry, I missed your question on Friday. I added an echo for each of those environment variables just before `cmake` is called and neither is set with a value.

I believe `cmake` infers which binary to use based on the Microsoft build tools being available in the `PATH`:

Here's the `mingw32-make V=1` output when building DOtherSide on my Windows 10 laptop, with the `echo`s added that I mentioned above:

                -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \

                -DENABLE_TESTS=OFF \

I see, thanks for showing that. I guess I have figure out from one of the issues you posted in OP what else I have to install and how it needs to be added to the `PATH`. Thanks!

This article shows how one can install Microsoft Visual C++ Build Tools with a command line call:
```
vs_buildtools.exe --quiet --wait --norestart --nocache --installPath C:\BuildTools
```
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/install/build-tools-container?view=vs-2019

I've installed it in https://github.com/status-im/infra-ci/commit/f0b9de71 and it seems to work:

It appears that the Jenkins agent service randomly doesn't start when the host is recreated:
```
Creating Jenkins Agent service...
10:17:11,483 - Installing service 'Jenkins Agent (JenkinsAgent)'...
10:17:11,540 - Unhandled exception
10:17:11,873 - Unhandled exception
10:17:12,148 - Unhandled exception
```
Other times it does:
```
Starting service 'Jenkins Agent (JenkinsAgent)'...
Service 'Jenkins Agent (JenkinsAgent)' started successfully.
```
Makes no fucking sense...

I have added `/c/BuildTools/MSBuild/Current/Bin` to `PATH` but I'm getting the same error:
```
[2020-09-23T11:12:29.771Z] CMake Error: CMAKE_C_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage
[2020-09-23T11:12:29.771Z] CMake Error: CMAKE_CXX_COMPILER not set, after EnableLanguage
```

Sans a bunch of duplicates and some totally irrelevant paths.
The interesting ones amongst those are:

* `/c/Go/bin`
* `/c/Qt/5.14.2/msvc2017_64/bin`
* `/c/Qt/Tools/CMake_64/bin`
* `/c/Qt/Tools/mingw730_64/bin`
* `/c/Users/sur_e/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft VS Code/bin`

@jrainville could you also show me where make finds the C Compiler? For @michaelsbradleyjr it was this:
```
-- Check for working C compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2017/BuildTools/VC/Tools/MSVC/14.16.27023/bin/Hostx86/x64/cl.exe
```
But I wonder where that's found for you.

@jakubgs :
```
-- Check for working C compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/BuildTools/VC/Tools/MSVC/14.16.27023/bin/HostX64/x64/cl.exe
-- Check for working C compiler: C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Visual Studio/2019/BuildTools/VC/Tools/MSVC/14.16.27023/bin/HostX64/x64/cl.exe - works
```
I see, thanks!

@michaelsbradleyjr found an interesting issue about installing VS Build Tools:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56419556/how-do-you-get-cl-exe-if-msbuild-must-be-installed-via-command-line/56419557#56419557

It states that:
>Adding Microsoft.VisualStudio.Component.VC.Tools.x86.x64 will install MSVC, including CL.exe:
>
>```
>RUN ./vs_buildtools.exe --quiet --norestart --nocache --wait \
>    --add Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workload.MSBuildTools \
>    --add Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workload.VCTools \
>    --add Microsoft.VisualStudio.Component.VC.Tools.x86.x64
>```
>If you look at "Visual Studio Build Tools component directory", MSVC is listed as a "Recommended" dependency type. Only "Required" components of get added for a given workload, so you must either use the flag `--includeRecommended` or `--includeOptional`, or append specific components that are not labeled as required.

Looks like that worked!
```

```

https://ci.status.im/job/nim-status-client/job/windows/job/ci-windows-builds/25/console

The specific error is:
```
error MSB8020: The build tools for Visual Studio 2017 (Platform Toolset = 'v141') cannot be found.
To build using the v141 build tools, please install Visual Studio 2017 build tools.
Alternatively, you may upgrade to the current Visual Studio tools by selecting the Project menu or right-click the solution, and then selecting "Retarget solution"
```
I've downgraded the Build Tools to `16.7.4` in https://github.com/status-im/infra-ci/commit/56335223

I found names of components for Build Tools on this site:
| Name | ID |
|------|----|
| Windows 8.1 SDK And UCRT SDK | Microsoft.VisualStudio.ComponentGroup.NativeDesktop.Win81 |
| Windows 10 SDK (10.0.14393.0) | Microsoft.VisualStudio.Component.Windows10SDK.14393 |
| Windows 10 SDK (10.0.10586.0) | Microsoft.VisualStudio.Component.Windows10SDK.10586 |
| Windows 10 SDK (10.0.10240.0) | Microsoft.VisualStudio.Component.Windows10SDK.10240 |

https://devblogs.microsoft.com/cppblog/finding-the-visual-c-compiler-tools-in-visual-studio-2017/

I don't understand why I have to spend 15 minutes googling to find this instead of being able to run something like:
```
./vs_buildtools.exe --list-modules
```

I think you should be able to use the 2019 Build Tools, but you need to install a certain version of the *Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable*:

https://github.com/status-im/nim-status-client/blob/master/Makefile#L168

The `-T"v141"` pertains to the [2017 Redistributable](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/porting/binary-compat-2015-2017?view=vs-2019) but there's a combo version for 20152019 (I see that installed on my laptop). Sorry if this wasn't clear earlier, I guess I took it for granted that installing the Build Tools would get you the redistributable.
